data.title: Wheeler Dealers' Mike Brewer admits ‘hideous’ classic car he would never restore
data.meta_description: Wheeler Dealers star Mike Brewer has admitted that a car built by an iconic American brand was his 'nemesis' vehicle.
data.text:
Wheeler Dealers host Mike Brewer has revealed the one classic car he would never restore as he branded the iconic vehicle his “kryptonite”.

Mike has restored over 300 vehicles on Wheeler Dealers tackling everything from off-roaders to sportscars.

However, Mike opted for an American muscle car as his pick, branding the vehicle “hideous” in a damning attack.

Mike made the admission on an online Q&A on the Wheeler Dealers Facebook page as he answered viewers' questions ahead of the latest series.

He said: “Do you know what. I’ve never been asked that. What car would I never do? Yeah there is. It's a great question.”

READ MORE Wheeler Dealer's advice to classic car owners with some models set to 'decay'

He quickly identified the Chrysler PT Cruiser Convertible as the car in question before explaining why he wasn’t a fan.

Mike commented: “Apologies to anyone out there who’s got one and likes them but I'm pretty vocal about how much I don't like them

“It would be a Chrysler PT cruiser, convertible, in yellow. That would be my nemesis. That’s my kryptonite.

"I can't stand yellow cars and I can't stand the PT cruiser and I can't stand a convertible even more."

DON'T MISS

He claimed: "They are just hideous. Some kid after he took an overdose of Calpol got a crayon and drew the worst design ever. He needs a punch whoever designed it. He does. Sorry if you've got one. It's hideous.”

The two-door convertible PT Cruiser hit the market in 2005 and was produced for three years before production came to an end.

It was based on the five-door hatchback Chrysler PT Cruiser model which was still being manufactured up until 2010.

The Convertible specification came with 220bhp and could reach a top speed of around 124mph.

The vehicle had the potential to reach 0-62mph in just over 10 seconds. According to AutoTrader, the leading marketplace for new and used cars in the UK, Chrysler PT Cruiser models are available to purchase second-hand.

However, they appear very rare with just five models on sale across the entire country at the time of writing.

Based on current prices, motorists interested in securing a used model should expect to pay anywhere between £2,500 and £3,000.
